questions.text: A 61-year-old woman comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. Her last Pap smear 3 years ago showed atypical squamous cells of undetermined significance. Testing for human papillomavirus was negative at that time. On questioning, she has had fatigue and an increase in abdominal girth despite a 5-kg (11.0-lb) weight loss over the past 6 months. She has gastroesophageal reflux disease and Hashimoto thyroiditis. Menarche was at the age of 10 years and her last menstrual period was 2 years ago. She does not have any children. Current medications include omeprazole and levothyroxine. Abdominal examination shows shifting dullness. There is tenderness to palpation of the right lower quadrant but no guarding or rebound. Bimanual palpation shows a small uterus and a right adnexal mass. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Chocolate cyst of the right ovary

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Excessive proliferation of the endometrial glands can be seen in endometrial cancer, which typically affects postmenopausal women with a history of prolonged estrogen exposure (e.g., due to nulliparity). However, the characteristic manifestation of endometrial cancer is vaginal bleeding. In addition, endometrial cancer is usually not associated with an adnexal mass.

Hyperproliferation of the endometrium may also be seen in estrogen-producing sex cord-stromal tumors of the ovary (i.e., granulosa cell tumors or theca cell tumors). However, these tumors are very rare and other symptoms of hyperestrogenism are also expected, such as postmenopausal vaginal bleeding or breast tenderness. In addition, this patient has a small uterus on pelvic examination, making hyperplastic endometrium unlikely.

B) CORRECT:

In patients with an adnexal mass and symptoms of advanced ovarian cancer, serum CA-125 can be used as a tumor marker for malignant ovarian epithelial cell cancer. This marker should be used in conjunction with transvaginal ultrasound to assess the size and characteristics of the adnexal mass. In patients with a high probability of ovarian cancer, surgical evaluation should follow for a conclusive diagnosis. After diagnosis and initiation of treatment for ovarian cancer, CA-125 levels can be used as a prognostic marker and for the assessment of treatment response.

Serum CA-125 levels are not used for screening in asymptomatic individuals at average risk because of limited sensitivity, specificity, and positive predictive value. Elevated serum CA-125 levels can be caused by other types of cancer (e.g., endometrial cancer, fallopian tube cancer, lung cancer) and, especially in premenopausal women, by a number of benign causes (e.g., endometriosis, pregnancy).

C) INCORRECT:

Elevated β-hCG levels in a patient with typical symptoms of ovarian cancer are consistent with certain malignant ovarian germ cell tumors (e.g., dysgerminomas, nongestational choriocarcinomas), which primarily affect female individuals aged 10–30 years. Epithelial ovarian cancer, which is more likely in this postmenopausal patient, does not cause elevated serum β-hCG levels.

D) INCORRECT:

Prolonged prothrombin time is typically seen in patients with impaired production of clotting factor VII due to severe hepatic impairment (e.g., in advanced cirrhosis). Hepatic impairment in ovarian cancer may be seen in cases of advanced hepatic metastasis. However, other symptoms of hepatic injury (e.g., jaundice, palmar erythema) would be expected and metastatic dissemination usually starts with solitary liver nodes that would not cause hepatic impairment.

The finding of ascites in patients with ovarian cancer is typically a result of fluid production of tumor cells in the intraabdominal cavity with obstruction of fluid reuptake due to peritoneal metastasis. Ascites in ovarian cancer is usually not the result of reduced oncotic pressure due to impaired hepatic production of proteins (which is the mechanism of ascites in liver cirrhosis).

E) INCORRECT:

Chocolate cysts or ovarian endometriomas can form when menstrual debris builds up over time due to endometriosis. Although endometriomas may manifest with an adnexal mass similar to what is seen in this patient, they usually affect premenopausal women. Furthermore, pain is a common feature in patients with endometriosis but is absent in this patient. Instead, there are symptoms of weight loss and ascites, which, especially in the context of an adnexal mass, are more concerning for ovarian cancer.

F) INCORRECT:

Cervical dysplasia found on screening Pap smear is associated with subsequent development of cervical cancer. Early cervical cancer is usually asymptomatic, but late cervical cancer is associated with vaginal bleeding, pelvic pain, or pain during intercourse, none of which this patient has. Ovarian cancer does not cause cervical dysplasia.

This patient's last Pap smear revealed atypical squamous cells of undetermined significance. Given the negative HPV test, her risk for high-grade cervical intraepithelial neoplasia is very low (< 2%).
questions.hint: This patient presents with fatigue, ascites, weight loss, and an adnexal mass, all of which are suggestive of advanced ovarian cancer. An important risk factor for this condition is an elevated number of lifetime ovulations due to nulliparity, early menarche, and late menopause.

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents for a well-child examination. Five days ago, her mother noticed traces of blood on her daughter's underwear while doing the laundry. The patient has had intermittent lower abdominal discomfort for the past 4 months but feels well otherwise. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. She is at the 95th percentile for height and at the 70th percentile for weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. The patient appears well nourished. Physical examination shows breast buds that are elevated and extend beyond the areolae. Examination of the skin shows no abnormalities. There is no axillary or pubic hair. The external genital organs appear normal. There is no vaginal discharge. An x-ray of the left wrist shows a bone age of 9 years. Serum luteinizing hormone concentration does not increase following gonadotropin-releasing hormone agonist stimulation. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's clinical findings?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient's intermittent lower abdominal discomfort in combination with signs of hyperestrogenism (e.g., premature menarche, precocious breast development) indicates an estrogen-secreting ovarian tumor (e.g., granulosa cell tumor, thecoma) as the underlying cause of PPP. Although granulosa cell tumors are more common in perimenopausal patients, there is a rare juvenile type that typically manifests with PPP and a bone age greater than chronological age. Because of the high levels of estrogen produced by these tumors, LH production is suppressed and there is no LH response to GnRH agonist stimulation. Pediatric patients with estrogen-secreting tumors are usually taller than their peers, but if the condition is untreated, they often have a short stature in adulthood due to early closure of the epiphyseal plate.

Patients with granulosa cell tumors may have a palpable mass in the lower abdomen, and pelvic imaging usually shows enlarged ovaries. Inhibin A and/or Inhibin B can be used as tumor markers. Regression of symptoms is expected after tumor resection (e.g., unilateral salpingo-oophorectomy).

B) INCORRECT:

For girls, the normal age of onset of puberty is 8–13 years, with the average age being 11 years. This patient presents with menarche and the development of secondary sex characteristics before the age of eight, indicating precocious puberty.

C) INCORRECT:

McCune-Albright syndrome may cause GnRH-independent PPP and occurs more frequently in girls. However, affected patients typically also have abnormal skin pigmentation (cafe-au-lait spots with ragged edges) and unilateral, polyostotic fibrous dysplasia.

D) INCORRECT:

Neoplasms of the hypothalamic region, such as gliomas, can cause central precocious puberty by disrupting the normal regulation of pubertal development, leading to increased secretion of GnRH. However, patients with central precocious puberty show an increased rather than suppressed LH response to GnRH agonist stimulation, indicating activation of the hypothalamic-pituitary axis.

E) INCORRECT:

Congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) leads to an excess of adrenal androgens, which are then converted to estrogen in the ovaries (aromatization). Patients with mild 21β-hydroxylase deficiency (nonclassic CAH) can present with normal isosexual external genitalia, PPP, and advanced bone age. However, pubarche and/or treatment-resistant acne due to androgen excess would also be expected. This patient has isolated findings of excess estrogen (precocious development of breast buds, menarche). In addition, CAH would not explain her intermittent lower abdominal discomfort.

Classic CAH manifests earlier in life with features of pseudohermaphroditism (e.g., clitoromegaly at birth) and signs of virilization (e.g., hirsutism), which are also not present here.
questions.hint: The development of secondary sexual characteristics and menarche in a girl < 8 years of age in combination with advanced bone age indicates precocious puberty. This patient's luteinizing hormone (LH) levels do not respond to gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) agonist stimulation, which is characteristic of peripheral precocious puberty (PPP).

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman comes to the physician with a 6-month history of breast tenderness and menstrual irregularities. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. An ultrasound of the pelvis shows a right adnexal mass. A laparoscopic right salpingo-oophorectomy is performed. Histologic examination of the adnexal mass shows small cuboidal cells arranged in clusters surrounding a central cavity with eosinophilic secretions. These cells resemble primordial follicles. Which of the following laboratory values was most likely increased in this patient at the time of presentation?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

A granulosa cell tumor is the most common type of sex cord-stromal tumor and is associated with elevated estrogen and/or progesterone production. Granulosa cell tumors produce aromatase, which converts testosterone to estradiol. Excess production of estrogen can cause breast tenderness and menstrual abnormalities, as seen in this patient. Unopposed estrogen causes the endometrium to proliferate, resulting in abnormal uterine bleeding and an increased risk of endometrial adenocarcinoma.

Although granulosa cell tumors predominantly affect postmenopausal women, in prepubertal girls, the excess estrogen produced by these tumors can cause precocious puberty.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of an ovary tissue sample (H&E stain; low magnification)

Granulosa cells (blue overlay) are arranged in clusters around multiple central cavities (Call-Exner bodies, yellow overlay). The characteristic grooved, “coffee-bean” appearance can be seen in some nuclei.

This is the typical histological appearance of granulosa cell tumors, although the absence of Call-Exner bodies in such tumors is not uncommon and does not rule out the diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) can be used as a tumor marker for certain ovarian tumors, such as dysgerminomas, which account for approx. 1% of all ovarian tumors. Dysgerminomas can also present as an adnexal mass. However, histologic examination of dysgerminomas would rather show cells with a fried-egg appearance (clear cytoplasm and a large central nucleus), not Call-Exner bodies. In addition to elevated LDH levels, patients with dysgerminomas can present with increased β-hCG levels.

C) INCORRECT:

α-fetoprotein can be used as a tumor marker for certain ovarian germ cell tumors, such as yolk sac tumors (ovarian endodermal sinus tumor). Ovarian germ cell tumors can also present as an adnexal mass. However, histologic examination of yolk sac tumors shows Schiller-Duval bodies (resembling glomeruli of the kidneys) in approx. 50% of cases, not Call-Exner bodies.

D) INCORRECT:

CA 125 is a tumor marker for epithelial ovarian tumors, e.g., serous cystadenocarcinoma, which is the most common type of malignant ovarian tumors. Serous cystadenocarcinomas are most commonly located bilaterally, as opposed to this patient's unilateral adnexal mass. Moreover, histologic examination of serous cystadenocarcinoma would rather show psammoma bodies, not Call-Exner bodies. Granulosa cell tumors are not derived from the ovarian epithelium and therefore do not produce CA 125.
Image Description:

Histopathology slide of the ovary (H&E stain)

In addition to papillary tumor cells, there are two Psammoma bodies located in the lower left corner of the image (red overlay). Psammoma bodies are concentric, lamellar calcifications, which are characteristic for serous tumors of the ovary.

E) INCORRECT:

β-hCG is produced by syncytiotrophoblasts and increased during normal pregnancy. Pathologically elevated β-hCG levels are seen in certain gynecological conditions, such as choriocarcinomas and dysgerminomas. Patients with choriocarcinoma often have a history of hydatidiform mole and ultrasound would show destructive growth into the uterine myometrium. Dysgerminomas can also present as an adnexal mass. However, histologic examination of dysgerminomas would rather show cells with a fried-egg appearance (clear cytoplasm and a large central nucleus), not Call-Exner bodies.

F) INCORRECT:

Physiologic effects of FSH include stimulating the growth of primordial follicles. Call-Exner bodies can resemble primordial follicles but they are not controlled by FSH. Patients with granulosa cell tumors instead have decreased FSH levels as a result of an increased inhibin production by granulosa cells.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of an ovary tissue sample (H&E stain; low magnification)

Granulosa cells (blue overlay) are arranged in clusters around multiple central cavities (Call-Exner bodies, yellow overlay). The characteristic grooved, “coffee-bean” appearance can be seen in some nuclei.

This is the typical histological appearance of granulosa cell tumors, although the absence of Call-Exner bodies in such tumors is not uncommon and does not rule out the diagnosis.
questions.hint: Histopathology of this patient's adnexal mass shows Call-Exner bodies (granulosa cells resembling primordial follicles), which are characteristic of granulosa cell tumors.

questions.text: A 64-year-old nulliparous woman comes to the physician because of fatigue and an increase in abdominal girth despite a 5-kg (11.0-lb) weight loss over the past 6 months. Her last Pap smear 2 years ago showed atypical squamous cells of undetermined significance; subsequent HPV testing was negative at that time. Menarche was at the age of 10 years and her last menstrual period was 6 years ago. Abdominal examination shows shifting dullness. There is tenderness to palpation of the left lower quadrant but no guarding or rebound. Bimanual palpation shows a small uterus and a left adnexal mass. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Chocolate cyst of the left ovary

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Elevated β-hCG levels in a postmenopausal woman are suggestive of tumors such as choriocarcinoma or other germ cell tumors. Choriocarcinoma often presents with vaginal bleeding, shortness of breath, or chest pain, usually in patients of childbearing age. It is incredibly rare in women over the age of 40. Germ cell tumors produce different symptoms depending on where they arise, but usually also affect a population under the age of 30. This middle-aged woman is at low risk for developing choriocarcinoma or other germ cell tumors. Instead, she is at increased risk for developing epithelial ovarian cancer, especially given her long estrogen exposure.

B) INCORRECT:

Women with excessive estrogen exposure from nulliparity, early menarche, and late menopause, as in this patient, are at increased risk for developing endometrial cancer. In endometrial cancer, endometrial glands undergo excessive cell growth and proliferation. However, early endometrial carcinoma is almost always associated with vaginal bleeding after menopause. This patient's symptoms of bloating, ascites, and weight loss in the setting of an adnexal mass are more suggestive of ovarian cancer, though.

Estrogen-producing sex cord-stromal tumors of the ovary (i.e., granulosa cell tumors or theca cell tumors) often affect postmenopausal women and can present with symptoms of hyperestrogenism, such as proliferation of endometrial glands, postmenopausal vaginal bleeding, or breast tenderness. This patient, however, did not have any of these symptoms and she had a small uterus on pelvic examination, making hyperplastic endometrium unlikely. Also, estrogen-producing sex cord-stromal tumors are relatively rare ovarian tumors, comprising ∼ 5% of all ovarian tumors.

C) INCORRECT:

When endometriosis affects the ovaries, blood may build up over months or years and eventually turn brown, forming what is known as a chocolate cyst or ovarian endometrioma. Although an endometrioma may present with an adnexal mass as in this patient, it usually affects premenopausal women. Furthermore, patients with endometriosis often have pain, which this patient does not have.

D) CORRECT:

Ovarian epithelial tumors are the most common type (up to 70%) of all ovarian tumors and are associated with an elevated level of serum CA-125. This patient has several risk factors for ovarian cancer such as nulliparity, early menarche, and late menopause. Given her symptoms and her risk factors, it is very likely that this patient's CA-125 is elevated.

This patient's CA-125 levels should be used in conjunction with transvaginal ultrasound to assess the size and characteristics of her adnexal mass, followed by surgery to conclusively determine pathology. After diagnosis and initiation of treatment for ovarian cancer, CA-125 levels may be used as a prognostic marker as well as a marker for how well the cancer is responding to treatment.
Image Description:

Intraoperative specimen from an en bloc pelvic resection of the uterus and uterine adnexa

The uterus and the lateral fallopian tubes (both within green dashed outline) are visible. The ovary located beneath the right fallopian tube (green arrowhead) is the normal yellow color and has a characteristic elongated shape and ridged surface. The left ovary contains a large, serous cyst (white overlay) with a gray wall, which has been opened up and, therefore, collapsed. There are nodular, solid carcinoma lesions on the inner membrane of the cyst (white arrows). Similar nodules (black arrowheads) can be identified on the peritoneum (green overlay) above the uterus, which may correspond to peritoneal carcinomatosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Cervical dysplasia found on screening Pap smear is associated with subsequent development of cervical cancer. Early cervical cancer is usually asymptomatic, but late cervical cancer is associated with vaginal bleeding, pelvic pain, or pain during intercourse, none of which this patient has.

This patient's last Pap smear revealed atypical squamous cells of undetermined significance. Given the negative HPV test, her risk for high-grade cervical intraepithelial neoplasia was very low (< 2%).
questions.hint: This patient presents with fatigue, ascites, weight loss, and an adnexal mass, which, especially in a postmenopausal woman, indicate an ovarian tumor.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of a 1-month history of dull lower abdominal pain, decreased appetite, and a 5-kg (11-lb) weight loss. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Pelvic ultrasonography shows bilateral ovarian enlargement and free fluid in the rectouterine pouch. Biopsy specimens from the ovaries show multiple, round, mucin-filled cells with flat, peripheral nuclei. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Decreased TSH levels in association with an ovarian mass, weight loss, and pelvic pain are seen in patients with struma ovarii. However, this condition typically manifests with only unilateral involvement. Additionally, biopsy would show thyroid tissue, which is not seen in this case.

B) INCORRECT:

Increased testosterone levels in association with abnormal ovaries could indicate polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) or Sertoli-Leydig tumors. PCOS can manifest with bilateral ovarian enlargement, obesity, and signs of hyperandrogenism such as acne, hirsutism, and menstrual irregularities. Pelvic ultrasonography would show enlarged ovaries with numerous anechoic cysts. Sertoli-Leydig tumors also lead to clinically apparent virilization with hirsutism and acne. Biopsy shows tubules lined by round Sertoli cells and interspersed Leydig cells, both in a fibrous stroma. Neither of these diagnoses fit with these historical elements and objective findings.
Image Description:

Macroscopic specimen of an ovary, transverse section: There are multiple, circularly arranged, brown subcapsular cysts (examples indicated by green overlay) on the subcapsular region, which are relatively small and of approx. the same size. This is the typical appearance of a polycystic ovary (see illustration for a schematic representation). In addition to the abnormal changes observed here, the ovary is frequently enlarged and as a result there is an increase in stromal tissue.

C) INCORRECT:

Pleural effusion, in the setting of an ovarian mass, raises concern for Meigs syndrome. Caused most often by an ovarian fibroma, this condition also classically leads to abdominal ascites. Krukenburg tumors may rarely lead to pleural effusion as well, but this would not be the most likely finding on further evaluation of this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Dark blue peritoneal spots seen in endometriosis are known as powder-burn or gunshot lesions. Endometriosis can present with bilateral ovarian enlargement and abdominal pain. Histologically, this condition appears as endometrial glands in normal endometrial stroma but with a preponderance of hemosiderin-laden macrophages as a result of chronic, cyclic hemorrhages into endometriomas. This patient's weight loss and pathology findings are not consistent with endometriosis.
Image Description:

A large bisected ovarian cyst

The cyst is filled with coagulated blood from endometriosis, giving it a chocolate-like appearance.

E) CORRECT:

A Krukenberg tumor is an ovarian malignancy comprised of signet ring cells that has metastasized from a primary site, most commonly the stomach. Signet ring cell carcinoma of the stomach leads to a grossly thickened and leathery stomach wall and is therefore also called linitis plastica (diffuse gastric carcinoma). The history of decreased appetite and substantial weight loss is explained by the primary malignant tumor. Metastases are typically found in both ovaries and often occur in conjunction with ascites, as seen in this patient.

Though the diffuse type of gastric carcinoma is the most common type of gastric cancer to metastasize to the ovaries, other types of gastric cancer, as well as breast cancer, endometrial cancer, and colon cancer, can also cause Krukenberg tumor.
Image Description:

Ovarian resection specimen

The ovary appears diffusely enlarged and has a smooth surface. The heterogeneous tissue contains streaks of cystic, mucoid tissue.

Krukenberg tumors are usually secondary to gastric signet ring cell carcinoma or breast cancer.

F) INCORRECT:

Elevated β-hCG levels are implicated in the development of theca lutein cysts. These typically are diagnosed in pregnancy and arise in the bilateral ovaries. Although many cases are asymptomatic, episodic peritoneal irritation as a result of cyst rupture can occur. Notable weight loss would be unlikely and histopathology would show hyperplasia of the theca interna cells but not round, mucin-filled cells as in this patient's biopsy.
questions.hint: This woman has bilateral ovarian masses that contain signet ring cells (round, mucin-filled cells with a flat, peripheral nucleus), which indicates a diagnosis of Krukenberg tumor.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. She feels well. She has no history of serious illness. She works as a flight attendant. She is sexually active with one male partner. Menses occur at regular 28-day intervals with a normal flow; her last menstrual period was 10 days ago. She had a normal Pap smear 1 year ago. She does not have any children. Her mother was diagnosed with ovarian cancer at the age of 63 years. She does not smoke cigarettes or use illicit drugs. She does not wish to have any children and uses oral contraceptive therapy. She has no known allergies, and her immunizations are up-to-date. She appears healthy. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 72/min, and blood pressure is 124/76 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. The patient is concerned about her risk for ovarian cancer. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Perform familial risk assessment using a questionnaire
Recommend barrier contraception instead of oral contraceptive therapy
Recommend annual transvaginal ultrasonography and measurement of serum CA-125 concentration
Perform genetic testing for BRCA1 and BRCA2 mutations

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Screening recommendations in the context of cancer susceptibility due to BRCA mutations vary. The U.S. Preventive Services Task Force recommends that women with a personal history of breast, ovarian, tubal, or peritoneal cancer or with a positive family history for these types of cancer undergo familial risk assessment with a standardized questionnaire (e.g., Ontario Family History Assessment Tool, referral screening tool for ovarian cancer). Risk factors for ovarian cancer evaluated by the risk assessment tools include personal or family history of ovarian, breast cancer, and certain other types of cancer (e.g., bowel cancer), age at diagnosis, number of relatives affected, and Ashkenazi Jewish descent. If the result of the risk assessment tool is positive, genetic counseling and, if indicated after counseling, genetic testing for BRCA mutations should follow.

Screening for ovarian cancer is not routinely recommended for women who do not have a personal or family history of the above-mentioned types of cancer because of a lack of evidence that supports such screening. Patients who are known BRCA mutation carriers and do not wish to undergo preventive bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy may be offered periodic screening for ovarian cancer (e.g., annual transvaginal ultrasound and CA-125 levels).

B) INCORRECT:

Risk-reducing salpingo-oophorectomy may be recommended for individuals who have a hereditary cancer syndrome (e.g., BRCA1 mutation, BRCA2 mutation, Lynch syndrome) and are not planning any future pregnancies. This patient's risk for ovarian cancer has not yet been evaluated yet.

C) INCORRECT:

Long-term combined oral contraceptive therapy decreases the risk of developing ovarian cancer and therefore should be continued in this patient. There are contraindications to this therapy (e.g., high risk for cardiovascular disease, known thrombogenic mutations, history of migraines with aura), but none of them are present in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Annual transvaginal ultrasonography (TVUS) and measurement of serum CA-125 concentration were previously recommended to screen for ovarian cancer. However, most guidelines no longer endorse these screening tests because of their low specificity and lack of survival benefit in the general population. In patients who are known BRCA mutation carriers and do not wish to undergo preventive surgery, annual screening with TVUS and serum CA-125 may be offered.

E) INCORRECT:

According to U.S. Preventive Services Task Force recommendations, genetic screening for BRCA1 and BRCA2 mutations should be considered in patients with a positive family history of ovarian cancer associated with BRCA mutations. Although this patient's mother developed ovarian cancer, it is not known whether she also had an associated BRCA mutation. Another step in management is more appropriate before proceeding to genetic testing.
questions.hint: The recommendation for this patient would be the same if she had a personal history of breast cancer.

questions.text: A 59-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0, comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. She reports a 3-month history of fatigue, which she attributes to her part-time job as a gardener. Her last menstrual period was 2 years ago. Medical history is remarkable for endometriosis and gastroesophageal reflux disease. Her mother died of breast cancer at the age of 64 years. She takes omeprazole and, occasionally, a herbal sleep aid. Vital signs are within normal limits. Pelvic examination shows a nontender palpable right adnexal mass. Transvaginal ultrasonography shows a 10-cm hypoechoic adnexal mass with irregularly thickened septa. Serum CA-125 levels are elevated. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Serial pelvic ultrasound is used to closely monitor ovarian masses in patients with no other clinical findings to support or rule out a diagnosis of ovarian cancer. This patient, however, has TVUS findings that are highly suggestive of ovarian cancer, which requires further investigation.

B) CORRECT:

Patients with an ovarian mass that has a high probability of malignancy should undergo surgical exploration and oophorectomy for definite diagnosis of ovarian cancer. Ultrasound features suggestive of malignancy include irregularly thickened septa, indistinct borders, and solid components. Because of the highly malignant nature of ovarian cancer cells, any disruption to the tumor capsule (e.g., during fine-needle aspiration biopsy) may result in malignant cell dissemination into the peritoneum, which significantly worsens the prognosis. En bloc resection of the mass with the respective ovary ensures tumor capsule integrity, which lowers the risk of malignant spillage. Patients with a confirmed diagnosis of ovarian cancer require further evaluation for cancer staging and treatment.

C) INCORRECT:

Fine-needle aspiration biopsy is a minimally invasive procedure commonly used for the diagnosis of newly developed masses (e.g., breast or thyroid nodules). In patients with ovarian masses, however, this intervention is contraindicated because any disruption of the potential tumor capsule could result in malignant cell dissemination into the peritoneum, significantly worsening the prognosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Cytoreductive surgery with neoadjuvant chemotherapy is the most appropriate treatment option for advanced ovarian cancer in patients with a high surgical risk or an extensive disease that cannot be treated with surgery alone. Although the characteristics of this patient's adnexal mass are suggestive of ovarian cancer, this diagnosis has not yet been confirmed. A different intervention should be performed at this time.

E) INCORRECT:

Genetic testing for BRCA mutations is indicated in all patients with confirmed ovarian cancer. Although this patient's ovarian mass raises concern for ovarian cancer, a diagnosis has not yet been confirmed. A different intervention is indicated at this time.
questions.hint: A hypoechoic adnexal mass with irregularly thickened septa on transvaginal ultrasonography (TVUS) in a postmenopausal woman with a 3-month history of fatigue and elevated serum CA-125 levels raises concern for ovarian cancer.

questions.text:
A 47-year-old woman reports abdominal pain and menstrual irregularities for the past 3 months. Her menses, which were monthly and typically very regular, are now sporadic and erratic. She complains of abdominal bloating and intermittent right-sided pelvic pain, not relieved by nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs or bowel movements. Pelvic examination is unremarkable.
Which one of the following evaluations is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Transvaginal ultrasonography is more sensitive than CT for detecting pelvic masses and provides useful qualitative information.

B) INCORRECT:

Endometrial biopsy is helpful in assessing a patient for endometrial pathology, such as endometrial hyperplasia, endometrial cancer, and benign endometrial polyps. However, it will not yield any information about potential adnexal pathology, which should be included in the differential diagnosis for any woman who has these symptoms despite an unremarkable pelvic examination.

C) INCORRECT:

Measuring a patient’s cancer antigen-125 level alone is not sufficiently sensitive or specific to be diagnostic. An elevated serum CA-125 level may be associated with pregnancy, menstruation, and many benign gynecologic conditions, including endometriosis, adenomyosis, uterine fibroids, pelvic inflammatory disease, and benign cysts.

D) CORRECT:

Although the symptoms associated with ovarian cancer are often nonspecific, any new, ongoing, or severe abdominal and pelvic pain, bloating, early satiety, or urinary urgency and frequency should prompt further investigation. Transvaginal ultrasonography is more sensitive than CT for detecting pelvic masses and provides useful qualitative information.

Key learning point: The diagnosis that should be considered in a premenopausal woman with menstrual irregularity, bloating, and abdominal pain is ovarian cancer.

E) INCORRECT:

Hysterosalpingography can provide information about space-occupying lesions in the endometrial cavity (submucous fibroids, polyps). However, it is not the most sensitive method for evaluating the endometrial lining, nor does it provide any information regarding adnexal structures. Hysterosalpingography is most useful for assessing patency of the fallopian tubes in the context of an infertility evaluation.

questions.text: A 64-year-old nulliparous woman comes to the office because of fatigue and an increase in abdominal girth despite a 5-kg (11.0-lb) weight loss over the past 6 months. Her last Pap smear 2 years ago showed atypical squamous cells of undetermined significance; subsequent HPV testing was negative at that time. Menarche was at the age of 10 years and her last menstrual period was 6 years ago. Abdominal examination shows shifting dullness. There is tenderness to palpation of the left lower quadrant but no guarding or rebound. Bimanual palpation shows a small uterus and a left adnexal mass. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?

A) INCORRECT:

Elevated β-hCG levels in a postmenopausal woman are suggestive of tumors such as choriocarcinoma or other germ cell tumors. Choriocarcinoma often presents with vaginal bleeding, shortness of breath, or chest pain, usually in patients of childbearing age. It is incredibly rare in women over the age of 40. Germ cell tumors produce different symptoms depending on where they arise, but usually also affect a population under the age of 30. This middle-aged woman is at low risk for developing choriocarcinoma or other germ cell tumors. Instead, she is at increased risk for developing epithelial ovarian cancer, especially given her long estrogen exposure.

B) INCORRECT:

Women with excessive estrogen exposure from nulliparity, early menarche, and late menopause, as in this patient, are at increased risk for developing endometrial cancer. In endometrial cancer, endometrial glands undergo excessive cell growth and proliferation. However, early endometrial carcinoma is almost always associated with vaginal bleeding after menopause. This patient's symptoms of bloating, ascites, and weight loss in the setting of an adnexal mass are more suggestive of ovarian cancer, though.

C) INCORRECT:

When endometriosis affects the ovaries, blood may build up over months or years and eventually turn brown, forming what is known as a chocolate cyst or ovarian endometrioma. Although an endometrioma may present with an adnexal mass as in this patient, it usually affects premenopausal women. Furthermore, patients with endometriosis often have pain, which this patient does not have.

D) CORRECT:

Ovarian epithelial tumors are the most common type (up to 70%) of all ovarian tumors and are associated with an elevated level of serum CA-125. This patient has several risk factors for ovarian cancer such as nulliparity, early menarche, and late menopause. Given her symptoms and her risk factors, it is very likely that this patient's CA-125 is elevated.

This patient's CA-125 levels should be used in conjunction with transvaginal ultrasound to assess the size and characteristics of her adnexal mass, followed by surgery to conclusively determine pathology. After diagnosis and initiation of treatment for ovarian cancer, CA-125 levels may be used as a prognostic marker as well as a marker for how well the cancer is responding to treatment.
Image Description:

Intraoperative specimen from an en bloc pelvic resection of the uterus and uterine adnexa

The uterus and the lateral fallopian tubes (both within green dashed outline) are visible. The ovary located beneath the right fallopian tube (green arrowhead) is the normal yellow color and has a characteristic elongated shape and ridged surface. The left ovary contains a large, serous cyst (white overlay) with a gray wall, which has been opened up and, therefore, collapsed. There are nodular, solid carcinoma lesions on the inner membrane of the cyst (white arrows). Similar nodules (black arrowheads) can be identified on the peritoneum (green overlay) above the uterus, which may correspond to peritoneal carcinomatosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Cervical dysplasia found on screening Pap smear is associated with subsequent development of cervical cancer. Early cervical cancer is usually asymptomatic, but late cervical cancer is associated with vaginal bleeding, pelvic pain, or pain during intercourse, none of which this patient has.

This patient's last Pap smear revealed atypical squamous cells of undetermined significance. Given the negative HPV test, her risk for high-grade cervical intraepithelial neoplasia was very low (< 2%).
questions.hint: This patient presents with fatigue, ascites, weight loss, and an adnexal mass, which, especially in a postmenopausal woman, indicate an ovarian tumor.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman comes to the office because she is concerned about her risk for ovarian cancer. Her mother was diagnosed with ovarian cancer at the age of 63 years. She does not wish to have any children and uses oral contraceptive therapy. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Perform familial risk assessment using a questionnaire
Recommend barrier contraception instead of oral contraceptive therapy
Recommend annual transvaginal ultrasonography and measurement of serum CA-125 concentration
Perform genetic testing for BRCA1 and BRCA2 mutations

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Screening recommendations in the context of cancer susceptibility due to BRCA mutations vary. The U.S. Preventive Services Task Force recommends that women with a personal history of breast, ovarian, tubal, or peritoneal cancer or with a positive family history for these types of cancer undergo familial risk assessment with a standardized questionnaire (e.g., Ontario Family History Assessment Tool, referral screening tool for ovarian cancer). Risk factors for ovarian cancer evaluated by the risk assessment tools include personal or family history of ovarian, breast cancer, and certain other types of cancer (e.g., bowel cancer), age at diagnosis, number of relatives affected, and Ashkenazi Jewish descent. If the result of the risk assessment tool is positive, genetic counseling and, if indicated after counseling, genetic testing for BRCA mutations should follow.

Screening for ovarian cancer is not routinely recommended for women who do not have a personal or family history of the above-mentioned types of cancer because of a lack of evidence that supports such screening. Patients who are known BRCA mutation carriers and do not wish to undergo preventive bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy may be offered periodic screening for ovarian cancer (e.g., annual transvaginal ultrasound and CA-125 levels).

B) INCORRECT:

Risk-reducing salpingo-oophorectomy may be recommended for individuals who have a hereditary cancer syndrome (e.g., BRCA1 mutation, BRCA2 mutation, Lynch syndrome) and are not planning any future pregnancies. This patient's risk for ovarian cancer has not yet been evaluated yet.

C) INCORRECT:

Long-term combined oral contraceptive therapy decreases the risk of developing ovarian cancer and therefore should be continued in this patient. There are contraindications to this therapy (e.g., high risk for cardiovascular disease, known thrombogenic mutations, history of migraines with aura), but none of them are present in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Annual transvaginal ultrasonography (TVUS) and measurement of serum CA-125 concentration were previously recommended to screen for ovarian cancer. However, most guidelines no longer endorse these screening tests because of their low specificity and lack of survival benefit in the general population. In patients who are known BRCA mutation carriers and do not wish to undergo preventive surgery, annual screening with TVUS and serum CA-125 may be offered.

E) INCORRECT:

According to U.S. Preventive Services Task Force recommendations, genetic screening for BRCA1 and BRCA2 mutations should be considered in patients with a positive family history of ovarian cancer associated with BRCA mutations. Although this patient's mother developed ovarian cancer, it is not known whether she also had an associated BRCA mutation. Another step in management is more appropriate before proceeding to genetic testing.
questions.hint: The recommendation for this patient would be the same if she had a personal history of breast cancer.

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman reports abdominal pain and menstrual irregularities for the past 3 months. Her menses, which were monthly and typically very regular, are now sporadic and erratic. She complains of abdominal bloating and intermittent right-sided pelvic pain, not relieved by nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs or bowel movements. Pelvic examination is unremarkable. Which one of the following evaluations is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Transvaginal ultrasonography is more sensitive than CT for detecting pelvic masses and provides useful qualitative information.

B) INCORRECT:

Endometrial biopsy is helpful in assessing a patient for endometrial pathology, such as endometrial hyperplasia, endometrial cancer, and benign endometrial polyps. However, it will not yield any information about potential adnexal pathology, which should be included in the differential diagnosis for any woman who has these symptoms despite an unremarkable pelvic examination.

C) INCORRECT:

Measuring a patient’s cancer antigen-125 level alone is not sufficiently sensitive or specific to be diagnostic. An elevated serum CA-125 level may be associated with pregnancy, menstruation, and many benign gynecologic conditions, including endometriosis, adenomyosis, uterine fibroids, pelvic inflammatory disease, and benign cysts.

D) CORRECT:

Although the symptoms associated with ovarian cancer are often nonspecific, any new, ongoing, or severe abdominal and pelvic pain, bloating, early satiety, or urinary urgency and frequency should prompt further investigation. Transvaginal ultrasonography is more sensitive than CT for detecting pelvic masses and provides useful qualitative information.

Key learning point: The diagnosis that should be considered in a premenopausal woman with menstrual irregularity, bloating, and abdominal pain is ovarian cancer.

E) INCORRECT:

Hysterosalpingography can provide information about space-occupying lesions in the endometrial cavity (submucous fibroids, polyps). However, it is not the most sensitive method for evaluating the endometrial lining, nor does it provide any information regarding adnexal structures. Hysterosalpingography is most useful for assessing patency of the fallopian tubes in the context of an infertility evaluation.
questions.hint: This patient should be evaluated for ovarian cancer, which is the second most common gynecologic cancer and has the highest mortality rate of any gynecologic cancer. Symptoms of ovarian cancer are usually nonspecific (e.g., abdominal pain and distention).

questions.text:
A 70-year-old woman presents with progressive abdominal distention, early satiety, and mild shortness of breath over two months. Vital signs are stable. Physical examination shows bilateral adnexal masses, a fluid wave, and diminished breath sounds at the right lung base (see lab result and reports).


Test
Result
Normal Values


CA-125
1,200 U/mL
< 35 U/mL



Transvaginal ultrasound: Large bilateral ovarian lesions
Cytologic examination of ascitic fluid: Clusters of adenocarcinoma cells

Which of the following diagnoses best explains her findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Endometrial carcinoma usually presents with abnormal uterine bleeding, not abdominal distention and bilateral adnexal masses. The ultrasound findings and adenocarcinoma cells in ascitic fluid suggest a primary ovarian process, not endometrial carcinoma, which rarely presents with such ovarian involvement.

B) INCORRECT:

Krukenberg tumors are ovarian metastases, often from gastric adenocarcinoma with signet ring cells. This patient lacks gastrointestinal symptoms and the cytology does not show signet ring cells. The elevated CA-125 level is more typical of primary ovarian cancer, not metastatic gastrointestinal cancer.

C) INCORRECT:

Borderline ovarian tumors, common in younger women, have low malignant potential and rarely cause extensive ascites with malignant cytology. The high CA-125 level and adenocarcinoma cells in ascitic fluid suggest an invasive process, inconsistent with a borderline tumor.

D) CORRECT:

Epithelial ovarian carcinoma is the most common ovarian malignancy in postmenopausal women, often presenting with nonspecific symptoms like abdominal distention and early satiety. The presence of bilateral adnexal masses, ascites, and a significantly elevated CA-125 level are indicative of this malignancy. The transvaginal ultrasound findings of large bilateral ovarian lesions and the detection of adenocarcinoma cells in ascitic fluid further support the diagnosis. These findings align with the typical presentation of advanced epithelial ovarian carcinoma, which often involves peritoneal spread.

Key learning point: Elevated CA-125 levels in the presence of ascites, pleural effusion, and bilateral ovarian masses are highly suggestive of an epithelial ovarian tumor, which is the most common type of ovarian cancer.

questions.text:
A 64-year-old woman presents with abdominal bloating, early satiety, and unintended weight loss. Imaging reveals a pelvic mass, and CA-125 is elevated. Exploratory surgery confirms advanced epithelial ovarian cancer with extensive peritoneal implants. A biopsy confirms high-grade serous carcinoma. Laboratory tests show normal organ function. She believes she can tolerate aggressive treatment.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: High-dose chemotherapy with hematopoietic stem cell transplantation
Total abdominal hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy without further therapy
Palliative external-beam radiation to the abdomen
Cytoreductive surgery followed by platinum-based chemotherapy

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

High-dose chemotherapy with hematopoietic stem cell transplantation is typically used in hematologic malignancies and certain germ cell tumors. In high-grade serous ovarian carcinoma, standard treatment involves cytoreductive surgery followed by conventional platinum-based chemotherapy. High-dose regimens with stem cell transplantation have not shown a survival advantage in ovarian cancer and pose significant toxicity risks.

B) INCORRECT:

While total abdominal hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy is part of surgical management in ovarian cancer, it is insufficient alone for advanced disease with extensive peritoneal involvement. In such cases, adjuvant platinum-based chemotherapy is necessary to target residual malignant cells, as surgery alone cannot clear microscopic metastases.

C) INCORRECT:

External-beam radiation is not suitable for advanced high-grade serous ovarian carcinoma with extensive peritoneal implants due to its diffuse nature. Radiation targets localized areas and carries a high risk of gastrointestinal toxicity. Systemic treatment with cytoreductive surgery and chemotherapy is more appropriate for managing widespread disease.

D) CORRECT:

In advanced epithelial ovarian cancer, particularly high-grade serous carcinoma, cytoreductive surgery aims to remove as much tumor as possible, enhancing the efficacy of subsequent chemotherapy. Reduced residual disease improves sensitivity to platinum-based regimens, such as carboplatin combined with a taxane, which target microscopic disease. This approach is associated with better overall survival outcomes in patients fit for aggressive treatment.

Key learning point: The standard management for advanced epithelial ovarian cancer involves cytoreductive surgery followed by chemotherapy to maximize tumor reduction and improve treatment outcomes.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old woman presents with several months of increasing abdominal distension and discomfort. She has no significant comorbidities and no history of prior surgeries or medical therapy for this condition. Her overall performance status is good (see lab result and reports).


Test
Result
Normal Values


CA-125
150 U/mL
< 35 U/mL



Imaging: Bilateral adnexal masses with diffuse peritoneal thickening and ascites
Biopsy of omental deposit: High-grade serous carcinoma

Which of the following management plans is most appropriate to address her disease?

choices.text: Pelvic radiation to control disease burden
Optimal cytoreductive surgery followed by platinum-based chemotherapy

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy alone is insufficient for advanced ovarian cancer, which is suggested by bilateral adnexal masses, diffuse peritoneal thickening, and ascites. The elevated CA-125 and high-grade serous carcinoma biopsy confirm advanced disease, requiring extensive cytoreductive surgery and chemotherapy.

B) INCORRECT:

Carboplatin-based chemotherapy alone is reserved for patients who are not surgical candidates. This patient, with good performance status and no contraindications to surgery, requires a combined approach of surgery and chemotherapy to maximize treatment efficacy.

C) INCORRECT:

Pelvic radiation is ineffective for advanced ovarian cancer with diffuse peritoneal involvement, as it targets a limited area. High-grade serous carcinoma requires systemic treatment to address widespread intra-abdominal disease.

D) CORRECT:

The patient's presentation, including elevated CA-125, bilateral adnexal masses, ascites, and biopsy-confirmed high-grade serous carcinoma, indicates advanced epithelial ovarian cancer. Optimal cytoreductive surgery aims to remove as much tumor mass as possible, enhancing the efficacy of subsequent chemotherapy. Platinum-based chemotherapy, often combined with taxanes, is effective post-surgery, targeting residual disease. This approach improves progression-free and overall survival in patients with this ovarian cancer subtype.

Key learning point: The mainstay of treatment for advanced ovarian cancer involves cytoreductive surgery followed by chemotherapy to manage the disease and reduce recurrence risk.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old G2P2 woman presents with a 3-month history of progressive abdominal distention and mild pelvic discomfort. She has no significant medical history. Examination reveals a 7-cm left adnexal mass. She is hemodynamically stable (see lab result and reports).


Test
Result
Normal Values


CA-125
65 U/mL
< 35 U/mL



Pelvic ultrasound: Complex ovarian lesion with multiple septations
CT scan of the abdomen: Possible peritoneal involvement

Which of the following is the most appropriate next step to accurately stage this suspected ovarian malignancy?

choices.text: MRI of the abdomen and pelvis
Percutaneous biopsy of the adnexal mass

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Diagnostic paracentesis can confirm malignant cells in ascitic fluid but lacks sensitivity for small peritoneal implants and does not provide a comprehensive view of tumor spread. It does not offer the detailed anatomic assessment needed for accurate staging and planning of cytoreductive surgery.

B) CORRECT:

Exploratory laparotomy is the gold standard for staging ovarian cancer, allowing for comprehensive intra-abdominal examination, peritoneal washings, biopsies, and assessment of omental and lymph node involvement. This procedure provides definitive histologic diagnosis and enables cytoreductive surgery, crucial for accurate FIGO staging. Imaging and elevated CA-125 levels suggest peritoneal involvement, but surgical staging is essential to identify microscopic spread and guide treatment decisions.

Key learning point: Surgical staging is the most appropriate method for staging ovarian cancer as it allows for direct visualization and sampling of the peritoneal cavity, providing the most accurate assessment of disease spread.

C) INCORRECT:

MRI offers superior soft tissue contrast but is not reliable for detecting small peritoneal implants or multifocal serosal involvement, which are critical for staging ovarian cancer. The existing ultrasound and CT findings already suggest malignancy, and surgical exploration is necessary for accurate staging.

D) INCORRECT:

Percutaneous biopsy is avoided in suspected ovarian malignancy due to the risk of capsule rupture and tumor spillage, which can lead to peritoneal seeding. It may not adequately sample heterogeneous tumor tissue, potentially resulting in an incomplete diagnosis. Surgical exploration is preferred for accurate staging.

questions.text:
A 68-year-old postmenopausal woman presents with three months of intermittent pelvic pressure and early satiety. She denies any vaginal bleeding. Past medical history is unremarkable, and her last Pap smear two years ago was normal. She reports no weight loss but notes occasional bloating. Physical examination reveals an irregular, firm left adnexal mass (see lab result and reports).


Test
Result
Normal Values


CA-125 level
520 U/mL
< 35 U/mL



Transvaginal ultrasound: 7-cm complex, predominantly solid adnexal mass with multiple septations
Chest X-ray: Clear

Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Refer to a gynecologic oncologist for surgical evaluation
Obtain an MRI of the pelvis
Schedule repeat transvaginal ultrasound in six weeks

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

In a postmenopausal woman with symptoms like pelvic pressure and early satiety, the presence of a 7-cm complex, predominantly solid adnexal mass with multiple septations on ultrasound, along with a markedly elevated CA-125 level, raises suspicion for ovarian malignancy. Surgical evaluation by a gynecologic oncologist is crucial for definitive diagnosis and management. This specialist can perform staging procedures and debulking surgeries if malignancy is confirmed, allowing for comprehensive treatment planning based on the disease's extent.

Key learning point: In postmenopausal women with a complex adnexal mass, there is a high suspicion for malignancy, and consultation with a gynecologic oncologist is crucial for appropriate management.

B) INCORRECT:

Broad-spectrum antibiotics are used for pelvic infections, which present with fever and tenderness. This patient, however, has a complex adnexal mass and elevated CA-125, suggesting malignancy rather than infection. There are no signs of infection, making antibiotics inappropriate.

C) INCORRECT:

While MRI offers superior soft-tissue resolution, it is typically used when ultrasound findings are indeterminate. In this case, the ultrasound and elevated CA-125 level already suggest a high likelihood of malignancy. Additional MRI would not change the management plan and could delay necessary surgical evaluation.

D) INCORRECT:

Repeat imaging is suitable for equivocal or benign-appearing masses, often in premenopausal women. This postmenopausal patient has a complex mass and elevated CA-125, indicating possible malignancy. Delaying intervention could allow disease progression, making immediate evaluation necessary.

questions.text: A 64-year-old nulliparous woman comes to your clinic with fatigue and increased abdominal girth, despite a 5-kg weight loss over the past 6 months. Her last Pap smear 2 years ago showed atypical squamous cells of undetermined significance, and HPV testing was negative at that time. She had menarche at age 10, and her last menstrual period was 6 years ago. On abdominal examination, there is shifting dullness and tenderness in the left lower quadrant without guarding or rebound. Bimanual examination reveals a small uterus and a left adnexal mass. Further evaluation is most likely to show which one of the following findings?

choices.text: Chocolate cyst of the left ovary.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Elevated β-hCG levels in a postmenopausal woman are suggestive of tumors such as choriocarcinoma or other germ cell tumors. Choriocarcinoma often presents with vaginal bleeding, shortness of breath, or chest pain, usually in patients of childbearing age. It is incredibly rare in women over the age of 40. Germ cell tumors produce different symptoms depending on where they arise, but usually also affect a population under the age of 30. This middle-aged woman is at low risk for developing choriocarcinoma or other germ cell tumors. Instead, she is at increased risk for developing epithelial ovarian cancer, especially given her long estrogen exposure.

B) CORRECT:

Ovarian epithelial tumors are the most common type (up to 70%) of all ovarian tumors and are associated with an elevated level of serum CA-125. This patient has several risk factors for ovarian cancer such as nulliparity, early menarche, and late menopause. Given her symptoms and her risk factors, it is very likely that this patient's CA-125 is elevated.

This patient's CA-125 levels should be used in conjunction with transvaginal ultrasound to assess the size and characteristics of her adnexal mass, followed by surgery to conclusively determine pathology. After diagnosis and initiation of treatment for ovarian cancer, CA-125 levels may be used as a prognostic marker as well as a marker for how well the cancer is responding to treatment.

Key learning point: Epithelial ovarian cancer commonly presents with an adnexal mass and elevated serum CA-125, which serves as a tumor marker for diagnosis and monitoring.
Image Description:

Intraoperative specimen from an en bloc pelvic resection of the uterus and uterine adnexa

The uterus and the lateral fallopian tubes (both within green dashed outline) are visible. The ovary located beneath the right fallopian tube (green arrowhead) is the normal yellow color and has a characteristic elongated shape and ridged surface. The left ovary contains a large, serous cyst (white overlay) with a gray wall, which has been opened up and, therefore, collapsed. There are nodular, solid carcinoma lesions on the inner membrane of the cyst (white arrows). Similar nodules (black arrowheads) can be identified on the peritoneum (green overlay) above the uterus, which may correspond to peritoneal carcinomatosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Cervical dysplasia found on screening Pap smear is associated with subsequent development of cervical cancer. Early cervical cancer is usually asymptomatic, but late cervical cancer is associated with vaginal bleeding, pelvic pain, or pain during intercourse, none of which this patient has.

This patient's last Pap smear revealed atypical squamous cells of undetermined significance. Given the negative HPV test, her risk for high-grade cervical intraepithelial neoplasia was very low (< 2%).

D) INCORRECT:

When endometriosis affects the ovaries, blood may build up over months or years and eventually turn brown, forming what is known as a chocolate cyst or ovarian endometrioma. Although an endometrioma may present with an adnexal mass as in this patient, it usually affects premenopausal women. Furthermore, patients with endometriosis often have pain, which this patient does not have.

E) INCORRECT:

Women with excessive estrogen exposure from nulliparity, early menarche, and late menopause, as in this patient, are at increased risk for developing endometrial cancer. In endometrial cancer, endometrial glands undergo excessive cell growth and proliferation. However, early endometrial carcinoma is almost always associated with vaginal bleeding after menopause. This patient's symptoms of bloating, ascites, and weight loss in the setting of an adnexal mass are more suggestive of ovarian cancer, though.
questions.hint: This patient presents with fatigue, ascites, weight loss, and an adnexal mass, which, especially in a postmenopausal woman, indicate an ovarian tumor.

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman comes to your clinic with a 3-month history of abdominal pain and menstrual irregularities. Her previously regular monthly menses have become sporadic and erratic. She reports abdominal bloating and intermittent right-sided pelvic pain that is not relieved by nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs or bowel movements. Pelvic examination is unremarkable. Which one of the following evaluations is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Endometrial biopsy is helpful in assessing a patient for endometrial pathology, such as endometrial hyperplasia, endometrial cancer, and benign endometrial polyps. However, it will not yield any information about potential adnexal pathology, which should be included in the differential diagnosis for any woman who has these symptoms despite an unremarkable pelvic examination.

B) INCORRECT:

Hysterosalpingography can provide information about space-occupying lesions in the endometrial cavity (submucous fibroids, polyps). However, it is not the most sensitive method for evaluating the endometrial lining, nor does it provide any information regarding adnexal structures. Hysterosalpingography is most useful for assessing patency of the fallopian tubes in the context of an infertility evaluation.

C) CORRECT:

Although the symptoms associated with ovarian cancer are often nonspecific, any new, ongoing, or severe abdominal and pelvic pain, bloating, early satiety, or urinary urgency and frequency should prompt further investigation. Transvaginal ultrasonography is more sensitive than CT for detecting pelvic masses and provides useful qualitative information.

Key learning point: The diagnosis that should be considered in a premenopausal woman with menstrual irregularity, bloating, and abdominal pain is ovarian cancer.

D) INCORRECT:

Measuring a patient’s cancer antigen-125 level alone is not sufficiently sensitive or specific to be diagnostic. An elevated serum CA-125 level may be associated with pregnancy, menstruation, and many benign gynecologic conditions, including endometriosis, adenomyosis, uterine fibroids, pelvic inflammatory disease, and benign cysts.

E) INCORRECT:

Transvaginal ultrasonography is more sensitive than CT for detecting pelvic masses and provides useful qualitative information.
questions.hint: This patient should be evaluated for ovarian cancer, which is the second most common gynecologic cancer and has the highest mortality rate of any gynecologic cancer. Symptoms of ovarian cancer are usually nonspecific (e.g., abdominal pain and distention).

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman comes to your clinic because she is concerned about her risk for ovarian cancer. Her mother was diagnosed with ovarian cancer at age 63. She does not wish to have children and is currently using oral contraceptives. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Recommend barrier contraception instead of oral contraceptive therapy.
Perform genetic testing for BRCA1 and BRCA2 mutations.
Perform familial risk assessment using a questionnaire.
Recommend annual transvaginal ultrasonography and measurement of serum CA-125 concentration.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Long-term combined oral contraceptive therapy decreases the risk of developing ovarian cancer and therefore should be continued in this patient. There are contraindications to this therapy (e.g., high risk for cardiovascular disease, known thrombogenic mutations, history of migraines with aura), but none of them are present in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

According to the CTFPHC, genetic screening for BRCA1 and BRCA2 mutations should be considered in patients with a positive family history of ovarian cancer associated with BRCA mutations. Although this patient's mother developed ovarian cancer, it is not known whether she also had an associated BRCA mutation. Another step in management is more appropriate before proceeding to genetic testing.

C) CORRECT:

Screening recommendations in the context of cancer susceptibility due to BRCA mutations vary. The CTFPHC recommends that women with a personal history of breast, ovarian, tubal, or peritoneal cancer or with a positive family history for these types of cancer undergo familial risk assessment with a standardized questionnaire (e.g., Ontario Family History Assessment Tool, referral screening tool for ovarian cancer). Risk factors for ovarian cancer evaluated by the risk assessment tools include personal or family history of ovarian, breast cancer, and certain other types of cancer (e.g., bowel cancer), age at diagnosis, number of relatives affected, and Ashkenazi Jewish descent. If the result of the risk assessment tool is positive, genetic counseling and, if indicated after counseling, genetic testing for BRCA mutations should follow.

Most guidelines no longer endorse these screening tests for ovarian cancer (e.g., transvaginal ultrasonography, CA-125) because of their low specificity and lack of survival benefit even in patients who are known BRCA mutation carriers. Bilateral salpingo‑oophorectomy is the only proven way to improve survival in BRCA carriers; it is recommended at age 35–40 years for BRCA1 carriers and at age 40–45 years for BRCA2 carriers.

Key learning point: Initial assessment of ovarian cancer risk should begin with a standardized familial risk questionnaire before considering genetic testing or preventive interventions.

D) INCORRECT:

Annual transvaginal ultrasonography (TVUS) and measurement of serum CA-125 concentration were previously recommended to screen for ovarian cancer. However, most guidelines no longer endorse these screening tests because of their low specificity and lack of survival benefit even in patients who are known BRCA mutation carriers.

E) INCORRECT:

Risk-reducing salpingo-oophorectomy may be recommended for individuals who have a hereditary cancer syndrome (e.g., BRCA1 mutation, BRCA2 mutation, Lynch syndrome) and are not planning any future pregnancies. This patient's risk for ovarian cancer has not yet been evaluated yet.
questions.hint: The recommendation for this patient would be the same if she had a personal history of breast cancer.
